entry.title: Bringing Substation Automation to the Lab - Our IEC 61850 Simulator
entry.summary: How we built a powerful IEC 61850 simulator on top of libIEC61850, with OPC DA integration.
entry.content:
If you‚Äôve ever worked with substation automation systems, you already know this truth: testing and integration can be a headache.

Every time you need to validate an IEC 61850 setup, you‚Äôre chasing hardware IEDs, juggling SCL files, waiting for network configurations, and praying your test environment behaves like the real one.

At Deliverain, we kept running into this same pain ‚Äî over and over again.
So, we decided to do something about it.

‚ö° Why We Built It‚Äã

We wanted to give engineers, testers, and integrators a way to bring substation automation into the lab ‚Äî without relying on hardware, without complex setups, and without losing the realism of an actual IEC 61850 network.

Our goal was simple:

‚ÄúMake it easy to simulate, visualize, and validate substation communication ‚Äî anytime, anywhere.‚Äù

So we started building our own IEC 61850 Simulator, powered by the open-source libIEC61850 stack, and then extended it far beyond basic simulation.

üß© What the Simulator Does‚Äã

Our simulator emulates the behavior of real Intelligent Electronic Devices (IEDs) ‚Äî the same devices used in modern substations ‚Äî and lets you interact with them through familiar tools and protocols.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs inside:

üìÇ SCL File Support‚Äã

Just load your SCD, ICD, or CID file ‚Äî the simulator automatically parses and builds the IED data model for you.
No manual setup. No copy-paste errors.

üß† Model Viewer‚Äã

Visualize your logical nodes, data objects, and attributes through an intuitive tree view.
It‚Äôs like opening up an IED and seeing how it thinks.

üîÑ Multi-IED Simulation‚Äã

Need to simulate multiple IEDs talking to each other? Done.
Each IED runs as an independent instance, complete with its own configuration and data model.

This simulator helps bring substation automation to the lab ‚Äî enabling engineers to test, visualize, and validate IEC 61850 communication efficiently and realistically.

Stay tuned for upcoming posts where we‚Äôll explore:

  • Integrating with OPC DA / UA for data interoperability
  • Extending simulation to cover GOOSE and MMS messaging
  • Visual dashboards for IED performance insights

Written by VimalKanth Tummala, Deliverain Engineering Team.

entry.title: Welcome
entry.summary: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.
entry.content:
Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

Here are a few tips you might find useful.

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

  • 2019-05-30-welcome.md
  • 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

The blog supports tags as well!

And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.
